webTitle: Anite drops 13% after software group cautions on outlook

fields.standfirst: Supplier of testing software to handset makers says it needs a strong fourth quarter to meet expectations
fields.body:
One of the day's biggest fallers is Anite, which supplies handset testing software to the likes of Samsung and Ericsson and technology to the travel sector.

Its shares have dropped 20.5p to 134.5p, or 13%, after it warned it would need a strong performance from its handset division in the final quarter to meet full year expectations. It said third quarter sales reflected a quiet seasonal period, especially compared to last year when its customers were investing in 4G systems.

Revenues and profits for the first nine months of the year were broadly in line with expectations, but order intake remained below last year's level. Chief executive Christopher Humphrey said:

Anite remains on track to deliver good growth this year. As expected, we require a strong fourth quarter performance in order to achieve expectations for the year.

Panmure Gordon analyst George O'Connor kept his buy recommendation but said:

Anite says that it is "broadly in line" for the third quarter. The "broadly" qualifier normally means that something has gone awry and indeed we learn customers have been "taking time to release budgets at the start of the calendar year". As the critical handset business is normally backend weighted we feel that underlying message is that Anite is commenting that it has sales pipeline – but there might be risk to execution.

Vijay Anand, at Espirito Santo, said:

Overall, we don't expect any material changes to consensus forecasts. While the varying quarterly patterns create a degree of short-term uncertainty, in our view the share price decline appears overdone as the underlying industry trends are unchanged.

He also kept his buy recommendation, but James Goodman at Investec moved from buy to hold.

The tone is incrementally cautious, commenting that the third quarter returned to being a typically quiet period as customers release budget slowly at the beginning of the calendar year. This means an increased weighting to the final quarter, with a strong performance in the handset division required. We remain comfortable with our forecasts and maintain our target price at 157p.
Regarding outer year estimates, we are low in the range (principally due to expecting only 8% handset division growth) and today's statement could prompt the top of consensus to be trimmed back.

webTitle: FTSE 100 edges lower on China caution while Sage hit by downgrade

fields.standfirst: Disappointing inflation, factory output and consumer figures from China keep investors on the back foot
fields.body:
Markets have made a quiet start to the week, as weak Chinese data over the weekend encourages investors to stay on the sidelines.

But Sage has slumped more than 3%, down 11.8p to 337.6p as analysts at Bank of America Merrill Lynch cut their rating on the accountancy softwear specialist. Merrill moved from neutral to underperform and cut its price target from 330p to 320p.

Heading in the other direction following a research note was SABMiller, lifted 42p to £34.37 after RBC raised its target price from £28 to £35.

Overall the FTSE 100 has slipped 1.49 points to 6482.09, as Chinese inflation came in at a 10 month high and factory output and consumer spending were weaker than forecast.

With China a key consumer of commodities, mining shares are under pressure. Kazakhmys - soon to depart the FTSE 100 - is down 7.5p at 525p while steelmaker Evraz has fallen 5.2p to 262.3p.

Banks are also unwanted, with Royal Bank of Scotland down 6.7p at 299.5p and Barclays off 5.1p at 313.5p. Matt Basi, head of UK sales trading, at CMC Markets UK said:

Equities have made a sideways start to the week, edging around Friday's levels as traders weigh the likely impact of higher-than-expected inflation numbers on Chinese government spending in 2013. The news has weighed on cyclicals – particularly in the banking sector.
Today's session may see bulls pause for breath, with little macro data on the calendar to provide the impetus for the next leg up. Final GDP readings for Italy failed to inspire much excitement, with an annual figure that saw the economy contract by 2.8%. The market is so used to absorbing weak European data that the slightly worse than expected reading barely raised an eyebrow.

Among the midcaps, Ladbrokes has climbed 15.8p to 241p after it signed a new software deal with Playtech, up 15.5p to 567p, to boost the bookmaker's online presence.

Meanwhile online grocer Ocado is up 4.7p at 139.2p. Supermarket group Morrisons, which has in the past been tipped as a possible bidder for Ocado since it has fallen behind in the online world, is due to unveil its new strategy this week. Morrisons is currently 1.2p higher at 264.2p.

Icap has dropped 11.7p to 330.9p as UBS moved from neutral to sell:

We are cautious on the interdealer brokers as we expect structural pressures on banks and thus on intermediaries to remain elevated. (1) over the counter clearing goes live in the US from March and in Europe in the second quarter of 2014; this will increase the cost of trading swaps materially and also lead to volumes moving to futures (2) European banks still have 5%-10% deleveraging to do (3) consolidation in fixed income, currency and commodities is set to continue.

webTitle: CBI urges George Osborne to kickstart economy by building 50,000 homes

fields.standfirst: Spending £1.25bn on affordable housing would generate £18bn for wider economy and create 75,000 jobs, says business group
fields.body:
Britain's largest business lobby group has called on the government to kickstart the economy by spending £1.25bn on building 50,000 new homes.

The Confederation of British Industry has reiterated its support for the government's austerity plans but warned the chancellor George Osborne that "now is the time to kickstart confidence".

John Cridland, the CBI director general, said building 50,000 new affordable homes would generate £18bn for the wider economy and create 75,000 jobs.

Osborne, who is putting the finishing touches to his budget to be unveiled next week, is under pressure to take bold actions to boost the economy – particularly in the construction sector. Output in the sector fell by 6.3% in January and is 7.9% lower than last year.

The latest figures from the Office for National Statistics and the Markit/CIPS construction purchasing managers' index survey indicated the sector has shrunk every month since last October. Construction accounts for 7% of the British economy.

Cridland said: "To boost the construction sector, we are calling for 50,000 new affordable homes to be built, incentives for refurbishing empty homes and the housing guarantee scheme to be extended to all types of housing.

"We must supercharge the NewBuy scheme to allow second-time buyers struggling to get on the next rung of the property ladder. With its relatively short lead-in times, house building offers the most bang-for-buck in growth terms – unleashing pent-up demand, while creating jobs and growth."

Vince Cable, the business secretary, attacked Osborne's economic plans last week and called for higher government borrowing to fund house building in the region of 1% of GDP.

"If you are talking about under 1 % of GDP that is hardly going to shake the markets to the foundations," he said.

Cable said there were "crucial sectors of the economy, like construction, which need a demand boost after being laid low by the bursting of the bubble".

The British Chambers of Commerce, which represents 104,000 businesses, also called on Osborne to invest in house-building and infrastructure projects. The BCC said 100,000 new homes should be built by 2015 by the government and by housing associations.

John Longworth, its director-general, said the chancellor should also redirect cash from the government's "failed" £80bn funding for lending scheme into ambitious road, rail, air and digital infrastructure projects.

"Government spending remains far too focused on unproductive programmes, rather than measures that underpin economic growth, wealth creation and prosperity," Longworth said. "With our economy teetering on a knife edge, it is not acceptable to protect wasteful current spending at the expense of capital investment and tax cuts that can spur long-term growth.

"Our own research shows that firms across Britain believe they can drive growth this year, but they can't do it alone. Time is running out."

He added that clear political commitment to major infrastructure projects would encourage pension funds and sovereign wealth funds to invest in Britain.

The EEF, which represents 900,000 engineers, also called on the government to redirect more cash towards infrastructure projects.

Terry Scuoler, its chief executive, said: "Having made it clear that it is sticking to its current economic course, the government must also demonstrate that it has the strategy to deliver the stronger economy that will pay down the deficit. This means accelerating action that will deliver public investment in key areas and unlock investment by the private sector.

"The government must deliver on its commitment to increase investment in infrastructure, redirect spending from other areas to support it and ensure that its infrastructure guarantees are bringing forward private sector projects. It also needs to develop a plan for increasing competition in business banking which starts to address a longstanding weakness in our finance landscape."

webTitle: George Osborne's bank reforms inadequate, say MPs

fields.standfirst: Andrew Tyrie, who chairs the commission said the regulator scrutinising ringfence would be 'marking its own exam'
fields.body:
A key plank of the chancellor's plans to reform Britain's banks in the wake of the financial crisis and the Libor rate-fixing scandal is "wholly inadequate", MPs have warned as they reopened the debate on breaking up the banks.

The parliamentary commission on banking standards said the government's proposal for the regulator, the Financial Policy Committee (FPC), to review the strength of the ringfence between high street and riskier investment banks was little more than the regulator "marking its own examination paper". It said the government should include a specific provision to consider a full, industry-wide split-up of the banks if the ringfence was judged to be failing.

"The government's proposal for the periodic review to be conducted by the regulator is wholly inadequate," the commission said in its second report on Monday. "Such a review conducted by the regulator would be little different in character from the regulator's annual report and could amount to no more than a case of the regulator marking its own examination paper."

The commission's strongly-worded comments come on the day MPs are to debate the banking reform bill in Parliament. Osborne is not due to attend the debate.

Andrew Tyrie, the Conservative MP who chairs the commission, said the government had "failed adequately to address our recommendation for a periodic, independent review of whether the ringfence is doing its job".

"Most witnesses, including the governor of the Bank of England, strongly supported this," he said.

Tyrie said it was "crucial" that the review was independent of the banks and able to keep up with the banks' fast-paced innovation. The commission also argued that the chancellor's agreement to "electrify" the ringfence, with the threat of a break-up for any bank attempting to flout it, did not go far enough.

Osborne has pledged to introduce powers to "electrify the ringfence" if lenders fail to keep high street branch operations separate from the dealing floor. "2013 is the year when we reset our banking system. So the banks work for their customers and not the other way round," he said in a speech outlining the bill last month.

Tyrie said Osborne needed to go further and introduce a "second reserve power for full, industry-wide separation" if the ringfence is breached. "This should be exercisable only after independent review and with Treasury approval."

Tyrie said the bill was "certainly much improved". "However, the government rejected a number of important recommendations. The commission has examined these again, alongside the government's explanations for rejecting them.

"We have concluded that the government's arguments are insubstantial. There remains much more work to be done to improve the bill."

The commission also called for limits on the risks banks take through what is known as the leverage ratio. The government has set it at 3% – allowing banks to borrow against their capital 33 times – while Sir John Vickers in the report by his Independent Commission on Banking had called for 4%.

The commission reckoned the FPC – the regulator in charge of financial stability – should be given the power to set the ratio.

Labour said the latest report from the commission made for "disappointing reading". Ed Balls, the shadow chancellor, said : "It confirms George Osborne is continuing to duck the radical banking reform we need and which the cross-party commission has demanded."

Balls said it was "astonishing" that Osborne would not be turning up to debate the bill in the Commons on Monday. "Our downgraded chancellor must stop running scared of these vital changes," he said.

The Treasury did not respond to request for comment as to why Osborne will not be attending the debate.

The report also raised questions over the time allowed for scrutiny of the bill. "The government has now announced its intention that committee stage of the bill will finish by 18 April. It is highly regrettable that the government appears to be compressing the timetable and railroading the bill through committee stage," Tyrie said. "The task of sorting out the banking industry, of which this Bill will form a major part, is absolutely essential for the long-term health of the British economy. Let's get it right."

The commission, which was formed in the wake of the Libor rate-fixing scandal, includes the Archbishop of Canterbury Justin Welby and former Chancellor Lord Lawson. The panel will produce a further report in May, making wider recommendations for banking reform.
